channel.title: Interesting Information About The Internet
channel.description:
3 miles underneath the ocean, fibre-optic cables run along the sea bed, providing the world with around 97% of its network.
Mean while, on a boat in the Pacific, men wait on 24/7 standby for a phone to ring. If it rings, it means a network provider has lost communications and they need the men to repair the under-water cables.
The cables get severed because the seabed floor is constantly collapsing due to the tetonic plates moving, and underwater volcanoes erupting etc. (this happens all the time).
Every time this happens, it costs the men half a million dollars to repair the cables. Ever had your ISP go down for a few hours? It's more than likely that the cables that provide you with communications across the world have been consumed by the seabed floor.
Richard Hammond told me that.

item.title: Interesting Information About The Internet
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

I am a phone/dsl technician. They will train me on fibre optics eventually. And if I wanted I could probably go into marine cables but that doesnt interest me.

I wouldn’t blame marine troubles when your internet goes out though. In a small region with about 30k people in the area, we get at least 150 calls per day which require repairs on the city lines.

Many of our orders are called eagle orders, which are troubles spotted by the ISP and not reported by the customer. Phone is not so fussy with the condition of your line. But for internet the conditions need to be perfect if you’re on copper lines. There are measurements we take and they have to meet standards for dsl to work. voltage, loop current, loop loss, power influence, noise metallic, real balance, stress, longitudinal balance, resistance, capacitance, etc

Read full topic

item.title: Interesting Information About The Internet
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

[quote=“Racist Turtle, post:26, topic:406679”] Speaking of Al Gore, I found this today, which was rather interesting. Even by sitting our asses on the computer, we are fucking up the environment in some shape or form.

I quote from this article: http://didyouknow.org/fastfacts/technology/

"One google search produces about 0.2g of CO2. But since you hardly get an answer from one search, a typical search session produces about the same amount of CO2 as does boiling a kettle.

Google handles about 1 billion search queries per day, releasing some 200 tons of CO2 per day."[/quote]Except that’s not the marginal quantity of CO2 produced, it’s the average. If everyone stopped using Google for a day it wouldn’t reduce CO2 production by 0.2g per potential search.

Read full topic

item.title: Interesting Information About The Internet
item.dc:creator: @Mendorphins Mendorphins
item.description:
@Mendorphins wrote:

So long as we stop cutting down trees and digging up oil so fast, we’ll be okay. Trees turn carbon dioxide in to oxygen, and the rest of the carbon, dead fish and volcanic ash, over millions of years, settles at the bottom of the sea and turns to oil. And then we pump it back in to the atmosphere.

Read full topic

item.title: Interesting Information About The Internet
item.dc:creator: @xryz xryz
item.description:
@xryz wrote:

[quote=“Racist Turtle, post:32, topic:406679”][quote author=Mendorphins link=topic=503677.msg3686252#msg3686252 date=1311870193]

Speaking of Al Gore, I found this today, which was rather interesting. Even by sitting our asses on the computer, we are fucking up the environment in some shape or form.

I quote from this article: http://didyouknow.org/fastfacts/technology/

"One google search produces about 0.2g of CO2. But since you hardly get an answer from one search, a typical search session produces about the same amount of CO2 as does boiling a kettle.

Google handles about 1 billion search queries per day, releasing some 200 tons of CO2 per day."

Interesting to know, but like xryz said, everything we do has some effect on the environment. It’s all over exaggerated.
[/quote]

Over exaggerated or not, does that mean we should do nothing about it?[/quote]

well we should do what we can but they just say all this to freak ppl out, and to make money off them. nature pollutes its self all the time: http://volcanoes.usgs.gov/hazards/gas/index.php , and http://www.thenakedscientists.com/forum/index.php?topic=15196 i havent read it all that stuff. i havent had classes that went in depth about the eco system and stuff, but im sure the earth can balance itself out. when u think green solar panels, wind gens, and hydro power plants u think oh that doesnt hurt the environment. yes they convert energy cleanly, but u have to consider how much did it take to manufacture those items, and how efficiently they convert each respective energy into electricity.

item.title: Interesting Information About The Internet
item.dc:creator: @Jerico_Pimpinbro Jerico Pimpinbro
item.description:
@Jerico_Pimpinbro wrote:

[quote=“IlikeArrays, post:19, topic:406679”][quote author=Jerico Pimpinbro link=topic=503677.msg3685191#msg3685191 date=1311799118]

satellite ftw?

Satellite internet is sadly not ‘for the win’.
[/quote]

I have a family member who has it and it really does kick ass. Maybe if your poor…[/quote]

Satellite internet has caps on it due to a FAP (Fair Access Policy) agreement. Once you reach that maximum your download speeds get cut to dial-up. Sorry, but I’d take highspeed with 40 latency over satellite with 1,000 latency.

Read full topic
